title: Worldwide Extinction Rebellion protests shut down cities from Madrid to Sydney
text:
Extinction Rebellion protests are taking place across the globe (Picture: AFP/ Reuters/ PA/ Extinction Rebellion Northern Tasmania)

Extinction Rebellion have promised to shut down more than 60 international cities with two weeks of global climate change protests.

The environmentalist movement, which uses civil disobedience to try and compel governments to act, says more than 850 worldwide events are planned across the next fortnight.

Cities such as London, Sydney, New York, Mumbai, Buenos Aires and Cape Town are all facing major disruptions as protests kicked off on the weekend.

In Berlin, activists camped outside the house of Chancellor Angela Merkel, while this morning hundreds of ‘rebels’ surrounded the Victory Column before sunrise.

The road between the monument and Brandenburg Gate will be completely blocked this week, police officials said.

Protests have kicked off in Brisbane, Australia (Picture: Reuters)

There is support for Extinction Rebellion in New Delhi (Picture: AFP)

Protesters link arms and block a bridge in Spain (Picture: Extinction Rebellion Spain)

German activists watched the sunrise in Berlin (Picture: EPA)

The Victory Column in Berlin has already been surrounded this morning (Picture: Reuters)

The movement has grown in numbers across Germany (Picture: Reuters)

Police say the road the to the Brandenburg Gate will be closed (Picture: AP)

While in Paris, hundreds of protesters barricaded themselves inside the capital’s Italie Deux shopping centre during Saturday’s events.

Advertisement

Shops were forced to close as the activists locked the mall doors, with many carrying banners which read: ‘radical ecology, death to capitalism’.

One protester, who gave her name only as Clea, told Associated Press: ‘It is time to change the situation and to say our society is going to a terrible disaster for humanity.

Woman who paid to look like Angelina Jolie is arrested for 'moral corruption'

‘We want to show we are here and we don’t ever give up.’

This morning in Spain, climate activists chose to ‘peacefully occupy’ the Madrid New Ministries government complex with a bright pink rowing boat.

Others were photographed lying across the bridge while holding hands, while some camped in the nearby plaza San Juan de la Cruz.

In Sydney, Australia, authorities confirmed that 30 people had already been arrested for refusing police orders to clear the road by the city’s Central Station.

Civil disobedience has begun in Amsterdam (Picture: AFP)

There will be a fortnight of disruptions (Picture: AFP)

There will be more than 850 events this week (Picture: AFP)

Arrests have been made in Sydney (Picture: Rex Features)

Most demonstrations started today (Picture: Rex Features)

A water tank has been displayed to ‘symbolise the drought crisis (Picture: Rex Features)

There is a growing police presence in Melbourne (Picture: Getty Images)

Their alleged offences included obstructing traffic and disobeying ‘reasonable direction’, officers said in a statement.

Elderly people and men in suits were photographed being dragged through the city’s main arterial road as they blocked the public from getting through.

Advertisement

Advertisement

A pink water tank was also placed in the area to ‘symbolise the drought crisis’, activists said.

Woman has baby despite being on coil which came out when she gave birth

Australian demonstrations are also taking place in Melbourne, Brisbane, northern Tasmania and Canberra.

Wellington, in New Zealand, has also been hit by protesters sitting on the steps of parliament, blocking the capital’s central business district and occupying a branch of ANZ Bank.

The country’s activism is being led by great-grandmother Mary Rose, 80, who said those involved are willing to be arrested for the cause.

She said: ‘I have been listening to people talking about climate change for the past 25 years – people of vision and wisdom. There is all this feeling helpless, what can we do.’

Melbourne residents have targeted government offices (Picture: AAP)

Protesters in New Zealand occupied a branch of ANZ Bank (Picture: Getty Images)

Activists were pictured lying down inside the bank (Picture: AFP)

Performances have been put on in Northern Tasmania (Picture: Extinction Rebellion Northern Tasmania)

Protesters in New Delhi have taken up road space (Picture: AFP)

A funeral procession was held in India (Picture: AFP)

An ‘opening ceremony’ for the protests was held in London by Marble Arch (Picture: PA)

Thousands will gather in the UK capital over the next 14 days (Picture: PA)

London has already seen swathes of protesters camping outside the capital’s core government buildings and blocking commuters on their way to work.

Hundreds held an opening ceremony at Marble Arch last night, featuring meditation and dancing.

Advertisement

Extinction Rebellion spokesperson Zoe Jones, 24, said: ‘We’re here to pressure the Government into action because we can’t wait any longer.

Second whistleblower 'backs up' complaint which sparked Trump impeachment probe

‘The next two weeks will involve marches and family friendly events, there’ll be some spicier actions as well and some will be arrestable.

‘We’ve had 4,000 rebels sign up and say they are willing to be arrested – which is a huge increase on the number arrested in April of 1,000.

‘The public perception of XR is that we’re disrupting ordinary people’s lives by blocking roads and that’s why this time we’re taking our protests to the seat of power and taking it to Westminster.

‘We are on the public’s side and we are ordinary people who are extremely concerned.’
